Lopeze l, R. Gomeza,l, A. Ramirez-Solisb, E. Poulainb, O. Novaroa* alnstituto de Fisica, Uniuersidad Nacional Autdnoma de Mexico A.P. 20-364, 01000 Mexico City (Mexico) bS.G.LA. del Instituto Mexicano del Petroleo A.P. 14-805, 07730 Mexico City (Mexico) (Received January 13, 1993; accepted October 6, 1993 ) Abstract Li/MgO catalysts were synthesized through the sol-gel method (using magnesium diethoxide and lithium chloride) and by traditional impregnation. FTIR results show that the sol-gel catalysts present higher hydroxylation as compared with impregnated ones. The features of the IR spectra are explained as the treatment temperature increases. In the preparation process of traditional impregnated catalysts much Mg (OH) 2 is formed which is later transformed into MgO by thermal treatment. BET areas are very similar for both types of catalysts. Theoretical semi-empirical Extended Huckel (EH) and self-consistent field (SCF) calculations were performed on Li/MgO model clusters to test the existence of [ Li+O- ] sites and oxygen vacancies. The EH calculations were done with Li concentrations varying from 2.66 to 15.9 wt.%. Results show a trend towards the formation of [Li+0- ] centers when Li concentration increases. This concentration effect is in agreement with the experimental results of methane activation. The SCF calculations using minimal and extended gaussian basis sets were performed on pure MgO and Li/MgO model clusters. These SCF results also show the creation of [Li+O-] sites which could explain the abstraction of hydrogen in the oxidative coupling of methane over Li/ MgO catalysts. Key words: lithium; magnesia; sol-gel catalysts Introduction Natural gas is a resource which should not be wasted as it is presently done in most petroleum drilling sites. Methane is the natural raw material from which many industrial products can be obtained. For this reason, recently, much effort has been devoted to design efficient catalytic processes in which the C-H bond (which requires 104 kcal/mol to be broken under normal conditions) is activated producing the CH3 radical. From these CH3 molecules many reaction routes can be followed that lead to methanol, formaldehyde, *Corresponding author; fax. ( + 52-5) 6161535. [ 1 ] have experimentally determined that the CH3 radicals constitute an integral part of these reactions and therefore hydrogen abstraction from methane becomes a critical step. From the experimental point of view, an interesting survey was done more than ten years ago [2]; this work tested a series of metal oxides that would promote the formation of methyl radicals into the gas phase from methane. The metal oxides that were examined included Si02, Bi203, A1203 and Mg0 which was, by far, the most active. A perfect MgO network would be expected to be inert. Nevertheless, Mg0 crystals contain a large amount of defects such as ionic impurities and vacancies. Besides this, the high surface area oxide contains sites of low coordination, namely, edges and corners. The remarkable catalytic activity of MgO for butene isomerization [ 3 ] and H2-D2 exchange [4] has been attributed to oxygen ions at low-coordination sites. On the other hand, Driscoll et al. [5] and Ito et al. [6,7] found that lithium-doped magnesium oxide was a highly selective catalyst and proposed a mechanism in which [Li+0-] species are the active sites responsible for the formation of CH3 radicals in the oxidative coupling of methane. These [ Li +0- ] sites would initiate the reaction by abstracting a hydrogen atom from CH4. It is widely accepted that the hydrogen abstraction step takes place over one oxygen ion site in the lattice, although a very recent study [ 8 ] of the partial oxidation of methane over a model MgO catalyst prepared under well-controlled ultra-high vacuum conditions indicates that [Li+0- ] centers are not likely to be directly involved in the hydrogen-abstraction step but that they promote the formation of color (F) centers near the surface of the catalyst which are responsible for this key step in the methane coupling reaction. Many other experimental studies have been carried out involving the oxidative coupling of methane over Li/MgO catalysts ( [9,10] and references therein). The activity and selectivity of Li/MgO catalysts seems to depend on the number of [ Li +0- ] sites formed during their preparation. Li-doped magnesia catalysts were usually prepared by wet impregnation of the magnesia support with lithium salt. The substitution of a Mg ion by a Li ion depends then on the hydrolysis of MgO during the impregnation step. An improvement in selectivity is observed when the lithium ion is added to a Mg (OH), precursor [ 11 ] . In the present work a promising alternative is reported: the Li/MgO catalysts were prepared by the homogenous hydrolysis of magnesium alkoxide in a solution containing ethanol, water and LiCl, i.e. the sol-gel method [ 12 ] . From the theoretical point of view there have not been as many works. Deprick and Julg [ 13 ] studied the adsorption of methane on (100) faces of pure MgO using the SCF method completed for the dispersion-repulsion term by an adapted pair potential. Mehandru et al. [ 14 ] used the atom superposition and electron delocalization molecular orbital method (ASED-MO) to predict structures, binding energies and electronic properties of the C-H bond break- T. Lopez et al. / J. Mol. Catal. 88 (1994) 71-84 73 ing process over Li/MgO catalysts. They used an (Mg21020)2+ cluster in their calculations. Zicovich-Wilson et al. [ 15 ] performed SCF-UHF calculations on a linear model MgO2X2 cluster (where X is a pseudoatom having the valence atomic orbitals of magnesium and a single electron) to study the oxidative coupling of methane over pure magnesium oxide and concluded that in this process a methyl radical is formed with an estimated energy barrier of 50 kcal/mol. In a later study, this group [ 16 ] reported semi-empirical (Extended HUM) studies on the oxidative coupling of methane over pure MgO and MgO doped with Li and Na. Finally, Borve and Petersson have reported two very interesting theoretical works. In the first one [ 17 ] they performed SCF, CASSCF and multireference configuration interaction (MRCI) calculations to study hydrogen abstraction from methane using a single MgO molecule. Their second study is more realistic and can be related to the catalytic process which is our concern here. In this work [ 18 ] they performed SCF, CASSCF and MRCI calculations to study hydrogen abstraction from methane using a reduced cluster embedded in a point-charge array to simulate the rest of the crystalline lattice intended to model the (001) surface of pure and Li-, Na-, Be- and Al-doped MgO. Their largest model cluster contained 11 atoms and hydrogen abstraction was restricted to occur in the colinear M (metal)-H-C direction. However, these authors never address the question of the existence of [Li+10-1 ] sites nor did they study the effect of Li concentration upon charge distribution near these supposedly "active" centers. In this work we present the experimental characterization (using FTIR studies and BET areas) of lithium-doped MgO catalysts that have been prepared using the sol-gel method. We also report the activity and selectivity results for the oxidative coupling of methane over traditionally impregnated and sol-gel Li/MgO catalysts. In order to test the [Li+O- ] site hypothesis in Li/MgO catalysts theoretical semi-empirical Extended Huckel (EH) and self-consistent field (SCF ) calculations were performed on pure MgO and Li/MgO model clusters. From the results of these calculations we discuss the effect of lithium concentration upon the charge of neighboring oxygen atoms as well as charge distribution on these model MgO and Li/MgO clusters. It is clear that these calculations cannot reveal whether the [Li+0- ] sites are actually responsible for the hydrogen abstraction step from methane or if these sites are only involved in the formation of near-surface F centers (as has been recently proposed [8]) which could be directly linked to the removal of a hydrogen atom from methane. The purpose of the theoretical calculations reported here is two-fold. Firstly, we intend to analyse the presence of [Li+10-1 ] sites through self-consistent field charge population Mulliken analyses; these centers have long been postulated but, to the best of our knowledge, no theoretical calculations to test this hypothesis have ever been done before. Secondly, one would naturally want to know the effect of lithium concentration upon the charge distribution of these 74 T. Lopex et al. / J. Mol. Experimental Synthesis of Li/MgO sol-gel catalysts A solution containing Mg (OEt) 2 (0.05 mol ), 0.85 mol of ethanol and 0.02 mol of ammonium hydroxide was refluxed under constant stirring. After 10 min of reflux of LiCI aqueous solution was added by drops in the appropriate amounts to obtain 1 and 2 wt. % of Li. The products were dried at 70 70'C for 12 h and then treated at 200, 450 and 600 C. These solids were labeled Li/Mg0 SG. Impregnated catalysts Sol-Gel (labeled Li/MgO-I-SG) and, as a reference (Li/MgO-I-D), the commercial (Degussa) MgO untreated supports were impregnated with aqueous solutions of LiCl so as to have a final Li concentration of 1.0 and 2.0 wt.%. The products were dried at 70 C for 12 h and then treated at 200, 450 and 600 C. Characterization Solids were studied by IR spectroscopy using a Nicolet MX-1 unit. Pressure was applied to the catalyst powder (no KBr was used) until the pellet was transparent. Specific areas were measured using a Micromeritics Model 2300 apparatus. Catalytic activity The activity of the oxidative coupling of the methane, defined as methane conversion, was measured at atmospheric pressure in a flow quartz reactor at 750 C. The feed gas ratio composition CH4/OZ was 2 and the contact time was 3.35 g s/ml CH4 PTN. Before activity determinations all the catalysts were treated in air during 1 h at 750 C. Little notable deactivation was observed under these conditions during 2 h of reaction. Theoretical calculations In order to test the hypothesis of a large charge variation on the oxygen ions in the Li/MgO lattice we performed semi-empirical Extended Huckel (EH) and ab-initio self-consistent field (SCF) calculations on some model clusters. The working hypothesis is that when a lithium atom replaces a Mg ion in the MgO network, the oxygen ion (or ions) next to this metallic site suffer a charge loss, thus leading to O- ions rather than 02-; formally this situation has been represented by [Li+0- ] sites. Catal. 88 (1994) 71-84 75 Extended Mickel calculations The semi-empirical EH calculations were performed using the program [ 19 ] on the 41-atom cluster proposed by Mehandru et al. [ 14 ] which consists of three planes of 9, 16 and 16 atoms (see Fig. 1); the first plane has a magnesium atom in the center. For different Li concentrations (from 2.66 to 15.9 wt.%) all structures were optimized with the fcc constraint. SCF calculations In order to determine the charge distribution in the pure MgO lattice and in the Li-doped network with as much precision as possible, we performed SCF calculations on some linear MgO model clusters that have been successfully used before [ 15,16 ] with extended basis sets and on 25-atom clusters with minimal basis sets. The SCF calculations were performed using the PSHF program [ 20 ] which includes the relativistic effective core potential (RECP) method of Durand et al. [ 21 ] . This leaves us with a [ Ne ] core and 2 active electrons (3s2) for each Mg atom and with a [ He ] core and 6 valence electrons (2s22p4) for each oxygen atom. The RECP parameters for Mg and O can be found in ref. 22. Two different contractions of the same gaussian basis set were used in order to perform minimal and extended basis calculations. The minimal basis sets, which we shall call basis A from here onwards, are the ones reported in ref. 23 with contractions (5s5p) / [ 5,5 ] for oxygen and (4slp) / [ 4,1 ] for magnesium and lithium. The extended basis sets used are of quadruple-C type for oxygen (5s5p) / [2111,2111 ], and triple-C plus polarization (4slp)/ [211,1 ] for Mg and Li. The extended basis set calculations on the linear 7-atom cluster involve 72 molecular orbitals while the minimal basis calculations on the larger two layer 25-atom cluster involve 100 molecular orbitals. a Fig. 1. Linear clusters Before performing any calculation on these rather simple clusters, we deemed it necessary to test if this model had a sound basis to study charge distributions in MgO crystals. It is well known [ 13 ] that the experimental charge of Mg is + 1.6 in pure MgO. We started by doing EH calculations on one-dimensional (with 11 atoms), two-dimensional (with 21 atoms) and threedimensional (with 31 atoms) linear clusters; this means that only the central oxygen atom connects the two or three perpendicular linear MgO chains. The charge on the central oxygen atom was -1.89, -1.83 and -1.78 for the 1-D, 2-D and 3-D clusters respectively. Since these figures are reasonably close to the experimental -1.6 value, for the SCF calculations we decided to use two linear Mg-O clusters (one containing 7 atoms and another containing 11 atoms) in order to study the central oxygen charge evolution with cluster size; both clusters had one oxygen atom in the center. For the one-dimensional 11-atom linear cluster, using the extended basis set which will later be described, the calculation already involves 116 atomic orbitals even using pseudopotentials. Here it should be mentioned that in order to account for the non-infiniteness of the Mg-O chains, a pseudo-atom (X) was used to terminate the linear chains at both ends. This pseudo-atom is described by the atomic valence orbitals of magnesium but has a single electron. This technique has been successfully used before in other studies [ 15,16 ] that used even smaller linear clusters than in this case. 25-Atom 2-layer model cluster In order to fill the gap between the rather simple model furnished by the linear Li/MgO clusters and the more realistic 3-dimensional model cluster (with 41 atoms) proposed by Mehandru et al. [ 14 ] , we performed SCF calculations on a sub-structure of this 3-layered (9,16,16 atoms) model cluster; we used the two upper planes containing 9 and 16 atoms respectively. This is equivalent to deleting the lower layer of the cluster in Fig. 1. The upper central atom was arbitrarily chosen to be oxygen. In order to study the effect of lithium/magnesium substitutions we placed the lithium atoms in different positions and made vertex, edge or central replacements. Studies on this subject Eire in progress and will be the subject of a subsequent communication. To study the possible effect of the methane conversion degree in the selectivity, two samples were tested at the closest possible conversion. Li/Mg0SG and Li/MgO-I-Degussa samples at 1.0 Li wt.% show the same activity; however, the olefin paraffin ratio is 50% higher in the sol-gel preparation. Thus, the conversion degree is not the most important factor in selectivity. The high selectivity to olefin formation of sol-gel catalyst must originate from the preparation method as claimed in a previous communication [ 26 ] . The addition of LiCl during the gelation of magnesium ethoxide or the impregnation of the sol-gel support with the Li promoter seems to have an important effect in the nature of the active centers rather than in their number. The exchange of a Mg ion by a Li ion in the gel results in the formation of centers that produce the successive oxidative dehydrogenation and, hence, high selectivity to ethylene. Self-consistent field calculations The pure Mg0 7-atom optimized linear cluster produced a central oxygen charge of -1.56 while for the 11-atom cluster this charge was -1.52. These charges are in good agreement with the experimental value of -1.6 of the real MgO lattice. Mulliken charges for the pure MgO cluster appear in Table 4. For this reason, subsequent calculations were made with the 7-atom cluster. With this in mind, we substituted one of the two nearest Mg atoms to the central oxygen by a lithium atom and proceeded to optimize this new Li/MgO model cluster. At this point it should be said that the only criterion we could use to optimize these clusters is that of energetic stability; this leads, of course, to interatomic distances slightly different (within 0.12 a.u.) from those found in the real three-dimensional lattice. The charge distribution found for this cluster can be seen in Table 5. These results indicate that when lithium replaces a magnesium atom the neighboring oxygen suffers great charge loss of more than one half electron which leads to an O- site. It is clear that the oxygen atom next to the substituted Li atom suffered a strong charge loss. This is in agreement with our EH calculations and with the proposed mechanism [5-7] and with the very accurate CASSCF+MRl calculations of B6rve and Peterson [ 18 ] by which an electron deficient oxygen ion abstracts one hydrogen atom from a C-H bond of methane. Conclusions In the FTIR spectra of the Li/MgO sol-gel catalysts a small shoulder can be seen at 3200 cm-1 (see Fig. 2), which evidently corresponds to the band attributed to Vl oxygen vacancies by Kirklin et al. [ 24 ] . This shoulder is absent in impregnated sol-gel catalyst Fig. 3. Even if no quantitative measure of the amount of oxygen vacancies in both sol-gel catalysts is given by IR results, the difference in both preparations techniques in this respect is quite evident. Even though sol-gel catalysts show a reduced activity for oxidative coupling of methane as compared with impregnated commercial MgO, they present a much higher (up to 8 times greater) selectivity to olefin formation. This fact casts some doubt on the very recently proposed hypothesis by Wu et al. [8] which states that near-surface oxygen vacancies with two electrons (F centers) are directly responsible for the hydrogen abstraction step in the oxidative coupling of methane over Li/MgO solids. If the oxygen vacancies were directly involved in hydrogen abstraction the measured activities for Li/Mg0-SG catalyst would be higher than those obtained for the impregnated Li/MgO-I-SG catalysts. The existence of [Li+O-) centers has been confirmed for MgO model clusters doped with 2.7 to 15.9 wt.% of lithium using Extended Huckel calculations and SCF calculations on reduced model clusters. In both types of calculations show a trend in the formation of [Li+0- ] sites as lithium concentration increases, a fact which is in agreement with the experimental results of methane oxidation. However our theoretical results cannot explain if the T. Lopez et al. / J. Mol. Catal. 88 (1994) 71-84 83 predicted [Li+0- ] sites are linked to the observed oxygen vacancies. In particular the EH calculations were specifically aimed to simulate sol-gel catalysts, since lithium atoms were considered in the bulk (not only on the surface) of the crystalline lattice. Li/MgO catalysts were synthesized through the sol-gel method (using magnesium diethoxide and lithium chloride) and by traditional impregnation. FTIR results show that the sol-gel catalysts present higher hydroxylation as compared with impregnated ones. The features of the IR spectra are explained as the treatment temperature increases. In the preparation process of traditional impregnated catalysts much Mg (OH)2is formed which is later transformed into MgO by thermal treatment. BET areas are very similar for both types of catalysts. Theoretical semi-empirical Extended Hückel (EH) and self-consistent field (SCF) calculations were performed on Li/MgO model clusters to test the existence of [Li+O−] sites and oxygen vacancies. The EH calculations were done with Li concentrations varying from 2.66 to 15.9 wt.‰. Results show a trend towards the formation of [Li+O−] centers when Li concentration increases. This concentration effect is in agreement with the experimental results of methane activation. The SCF calculations using minimal and extended gaussian basis sets were performed on pure MgO and Li/MgO model clusters. These SCF results also show the creation of [Li+O−] sites which could explain the abstraction of hydrogen in the oxidative coupling of methane over Li/ MgO catalysts.
